headline: Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Chipotle Mexican Grill Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would now like to introduce Investor Relations Manager for Chipotle Mexi
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Chipotle Mexican Grill Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would now like to introduce Investor Relations Manager for Chipotle Mexican Grill, Mr. Mark Alexee. You may begin your conference.

headline: Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Hello, everyone, and welcome to our call today. By now, you should have accessed our earnings announcement released this afternoon for the third quarter 2015. It may also be found on our website at chipotle.com in the Investor Relations section
componenttext:
Thank you. Hello, everyone, and welcome to our call today. By now, you should have accessed our earnings announcement released this afternoon for the third quarter 2015. It may also be found on our website at chipotle.com in the Investor Relations section.
Before we begin our presentation, I will remind everyone that parts of our discussion today will include forward-looking statements as defined in the securities laws. These forward-looking statements will include statements about potential business improvement in shareholder returns; projections of the number of restaurants we intend to open and trend in development costs and new restaurant return; estimates of future comparable restaurant sales increases or comps; and supply chain and other trends affecting future comps; projections regarding food, labor, marketing, occupancy and G&A cost and our expected tax rate; statements about stock repurchases as well as statements about our expansions and plans. These statements are based on information available to us today, and we are not assuming any obligation to update them.
Forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause our actual results to differ materially from the forward-looking statements. We refer you to the Risk Factors in our Annual Report on Form 10-K as updated in our subsequent Form 10-Qs for a discussion of these risks.
I'd like to remind everyone that we've adopted a self-imposed quiet period, restricting communications with investors during that period. The quiet period begins on the first day of the last month of each fiscal quarter and continues until the next earnings conference call. For the fourth quarter, it will begin December 1 and continue through our fourth quarter and year-end earnings release planned for late January 2016.
On the call with us today are Steve Ells, our Chairman and Co-Chief Executive Officer; Monty Moran, Co-Chief Executive Officer; and Jack Hartung, Chief Financial Officer.
With that, I will now turn the call over to Steve.

headline: Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark. I'm pleased with our performance during the third quarter and throughout the full year. With very difficult comparisons against the record year we had in 2014, we've continued to grow our business in the competitive environment while maintai
componenttext:
Thanks, Mark. I'm pleased with our performance during the third quarter and throughout the full year. With very difficult comparisons against the record year we had in 2014, we've continued to grow our business in the competitive environment while maintaining some of the best margins in the industry. During the quarter, we generated revenue of $1.2 billion, an increase of 12% on comparable restaurant sales growth of 2.6% and the opening of 53 new restaurants. This produced diluted earnings of $4.59 per share, an increase of 11%. 
With year-to-date revenue of $3.5 billion, comp sales growth of 5.5% and earnings per share growth of 26%, we are well on track to deliver another strong year. More than that, I'm proud of the fact that we continue to deliver such strong results by maintaining true to our vision to change the way people think about and eat fast food. We're realizing this vision through constant attention to our unique food and people cultures and by innovating to improve upon these key drivers of our business even in the face of challenges. During the quarter, we made significant strides to overcome a major obstacle tight our ability to obtain pork that meets all of our animal health care standards. Earlier this month, we announced that we have returned carnitas to 90% of our restaurants nationwide. As discussed in the last earnings call, we have begun to source pork from Karro Foods in the U.K. that is raised in the way that meets or exceeds all of our animal health care standards. Just like our current protocols, Karro does not use antibiotics nontherapeutically to promote growth in healthy animals. Karro follows European standards that allow antibiotics to be administered under veterinary supervision when necessary. We have been very happy with the quality of the property been providing in the care and respect with which Karro is treating their animals. Since beginning our relationship with Karro, we have also secured an additional pork supplier, and we expect to have enough pork to return carnitas to all of our restaurants by the end of November. We know that many of our customers love our carnitas, and we're disappointed we had stopped serving it in a number of our restaurants around the country. To all of our customers who have been inconvenienced by our carnitas shortage, I'd like to personally thank you for your patience and your support. We knew this issue would be difficult for our customers and our restaurants, but we also knew that suspending sales of carnitas in some of our restaurants rather than serving commodity pork was the right thing to do. And we're thrilled to see that so many of our loyal customers agreed with our decision. After highlighting this issue, we have begun discussions with a number of additional suppliers across the country that are interested in working with us to improve the animal welfare conditions and meet the standards we require for our pork. I'm so excited about this encouraging change, particularly when compared to the reaction we received when starting our Food with Integrity program a little more than 15 years ago. At that time, there was variable pork available that met our acquirements. But today, some of the largest agricultural producers are taking a much closer look at the way they raise their animals, and they are starting to see that we have what we have always believed that food grown and raised with respect for animals, the environment, farmers and customers simply tastes better. We're excited to be close to returning to carnitas to 100% of our restaurants. And to let our customers know that carnitas is back, we have been promoting its return in our restaurants through social media and with PR, so customers who have been awaiting this return know where it is available.
Of course, changing the way people think about it eat fast food requires more than overcoming supply change challenges. We focus a lot of our marketing efforts on educating customers through entertaining and creative purchase, which Mark will talk about a little bit later. And we're delighted that we continue to see evidence of Chipotle's impact on food issues. Most recently, the State of California passed SB 27, making it the first state in the company to pass legislation to limit antibiotic use in healthy life stocks and to ban the routine use of antibiotics to promote growth. We began serving meat from animals raised without the use of antibiotics in 1999 when we started serving pork from Nyman Ranch. Today, we serve more meat from animals raised without antibiotics than any other restaurant company. While we have been encouraged by even small steps made by other restaurant companies through this antibiotic use in farming and moves from some of the larger -- largest meat producers to embrace antibiotics practices to reduce antibiotic protocols.
The California bill is an important -- is important as it is the first to mandate responsible antibiotic use in livestock. This is an important step forward in the evolution of animal agriculture, and we hope that others will take similar steps in the foreseeable future. 
During the quarter, we opened our seventh restaurant in London, a small 5-day per week location in the financial district, which is intensely lunch-driven like our first stores inside the Loop in Chicago. It is off to a solid start and has been breaking our throughput records in the U.K. Additionally, just last week, we opened our fourth restaurant in Paris into a new neighborhood for us. Our growth seeds in Europe continue to build brand recognition and are at the front end of developing a loyal customer base. Our growth seeds here in the U.S. continue to show promise, and we have continued to expand ShopHouse and Pizzeria Locale. ShopHouse recently opened its fourth location in Los Angeles, bringing the total number of ShopHouse restaurants to 11, and we plan to open 2 ShopHouse restaurants in Chicago before year-end. Pizzeria Locale expanded to its second market during the most recent quarter, opening its first restaurant in Kansas City, and we plan 2 pizzas -- pizzerias in Cincinnati in the coming months. Very exciting to apply our strong food culture and our unique and empowering people culture to these growth seeds. We are changing the way people think about and eat fast food, and our commitment to that vision is the best way to deliver outstanding results for our shareholders. 
Last, we recently hired our first ever Chief Information Officer. Curt Garner will be joining Chipotle on November 23. He comes from Starbucks where he held the same position. In his 18 years at Starbucks, Curt helped build the technology infrastructure that began with fewer than 2,000 stores to one that now supports a global business. We believe that Curt's background and expertise will be a great asset to Chipotle as we continue to seek ways to accelerate our use of technology to help strengthen our business. We're very excited for Curt to join us and look forward to the value he will bring to Chipotle.
I'll now turn the call over to Monty.

headline: Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve. Our excellent results are possible because of the strength of our special people culture. By hiring teams of top performers, empowering them to achieve high standards and developing them to be leaders for our company, we are setting ours
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve. Our excellent results are possible because of the strength of our special people culture. By hiring teams of top performers, empowering them to achieve high standards and developing them to be leaders for our company, we are setting ourselves up to be able to provide a consistently extraordinary restaurant experience while also maintaining a strong economic model. Like our food culture, building the right people culture is an ongoing journey and is one that requires us to constantly push ourselves to find ways to get better and to raise the bar on the quality of the experience we provide. During the quarter, we've hosted -- we hosted our biennial field leadership conference to bring together all of our field leaders and support departments to talk about how we can strengthen our culture. It was a wonderful inspirational 2 days focused on how our field leaders can make a bigger impact in the restaurants and help our teams on the road to Restaurateur. We discussed the importance of instilling and inspiring vision, creating encouraging circumstances and how to best utilize our diagnosis and plan tool to identify negative things that are standing in the way of a restaurant achieving Restaurateur status. 
Our unique people culture also continue to gain traction within our growth seeds. As Steve mentioned, during the third quarter, we opened our seventh restaurant in London, and I recently visited the fantastic team there and was pleased to be able to sign them off as Restaurateur. Our European operations team, which is led by Jacob a team leader and Restaurateur, has been building outstanding teams to ensure that customer experience we are providing in these new markets meets our high standards and continues to develop strong culture in these restaurants quickly. To help us better plan for future growth, we recently hired Jerome Cassagne as our head of European business development. Jerome has decades of restaurant industry experience in Europe and is spearheading our planning process, including navigating the nuances of operating a new restaurant brand across several countries and identifying lower-cost real estate options in markets that are very expensive.
As European customers continue to discover and turn into repeat customers at Chipotle, we are excited for the leadership and insight that Jacob and bring, and we look forward to great things to come for this team.
As of the end of the quarter, we are proud to have a strong roster of nearly 500 Restaurateurs with an additional 30 restaurants ready to be signed off by an officer. Our past investment and field leadership is beginning to bear fruit, and we are confident those improved restaurant cultures will lead to better service and a more compelling experience for our customers.
Beyond our efforts to strengthen our restaurant leadership, we recently took a very visible step towards bolstering the in our restaurant as we held our first-ever National Career Day in September. We set ambitious goals to interview more than 30,000 candidates for this and through the event and surrounding publicity, we ended up hiring 4,977 incremental crew members. Not only are we excited about our new hires, but this event also created the significant opportunity for us to showcase our people culture and the unique career opportunities we provide. Although the overall labor market show signs of tightening, we have found that top performers are consistently attracted to the challenging work environment a growth potential offered at Chipotle. One of the leadership roles in our restaurants is the reliance will be referred to as a takeout specialist whose job it is to take care of our out-of-store orders, which are a growing part of our business. As you may know, virtually every one of our restaurants is equipped with the second line, which is an abbreviated version of the front line, where we serve our regular customers. Fortunately, the second make lines are gradually getting more used, and we're now averaging nearly $500 in days -- $500 a day in sales per restaurant on the second make line company-wide. In some of our high-volume restaurant, the sales in the second mate line are much, much higher such that is a virtually a second restaurant within the restaurant, which is a phenomenal way for us to leverage our existing kitchens. When we receive online fax or catering orders, a takeout specialist is magic the timing of orders through production and all other aspects of the guest experience, and preparing the orders to be picked up. Not only is the sales channel exciting, but it offers the additional benefit of improving throughput as the more people who use the second make line, the better the customer experience is for the rest of our customers who can quickly receive and enjoy a meal.
During the third quarter, our teams increased throughput during our peak dinner hour by 1 transaction, while nonpeak throughput counts increased by 9 transactions. Unfortunately, we declined by 1 transaction during our peak lunch hour, and our teams would be working on instilling a sense of urgency to continue to improve this important aspect of customer service during the peak lunch hour. We know that as our volumes continue to grow, our teams need to continue to achieve incremental gains to improve the overall customer experience. Better throughput is one key driver that helps us improve our unit economic model that over the years contribute to some of our best cash-on-cash returns. Another component for terrific return on investment is the great job that our development team has done on identifying locations for you restaurants while maintaining a reasonable capital investment cost. We a fantastic development program as our real estate design and construction teams are finding favorable new restaurant sites and negotiating some of our best lease terms. During the quarter, we opened up 53 restaurants for a total of 150 restaurants through the first 9 months of this year. This is the fastest that we've ever added new stores, and we're not done yet. Our teams have been working diligently, and we're increasing our guidance for the full year 2015 to a range of 215 to 225 new Chipotles.
What's even more encouraging is that we're able to complete these restaurants in what is arguably one of the most competitive real estate markets we've seen in recent years. Our teams have given us feedback that the competition for new site locations remains high, and the demand for talented contractors, subcontractors and crews is intense as many developers are taking advantage of the current low interest rate environment. Despite these pressures, we continue to focus identify an optimal mix of and in-line restaurants that have actually allowed us to lower our average investment cost. Also, Chipotle remains a preferred tenant for many landlords, and that places us in a strong position to negotiate favorable lease and tenant improvement terms and also helps get into properties even where demand is very high. As we think about 2016 new unit development, we expect to open you restaurants at an even faster pace and are currently projecting a range of 220 to 235 new restaurants for next year.
I'll now turn the call over to Mark.

headline: Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Monty. During the quarter, we continued our efforts to educate consumers about our food and our unique food culture through innovative programs. In our promotion we called "friends or faux," we challenged consumers to identify real friendly ing
componenttext:
Thank you, Monty. During the quarter, we continued our efforts to educate consumers about our food and our unique food culture through innovative programs. In our promotion we called "friends or faux," we challenged consumers to identify real friendly ingredients that align with our Food with Integrity vision and faux ingredients, artificial flavors preservatives and additives by comparing our food to a representative set of food meals such as burgers sub sandwiches and that are often manufactured with highly processed ingredients. People who can play the game could win a "buy one get one" offer at Chipotle simply by comparing what's in our food against what's in traditional fast food. The idea for this promotion will show -- was to show the simplicity of Chipotle's food, all of which is classically prepared from just 68 ingredients across our entire menu compared to a typical fast food where a single menu item can have upwards of 100 ingredients, many of which are chemical additives. The program launched in July, and consumer participation exceeded our expectations with more than 750,000 people playing the game within the first 24 hours. In total, the program generated an average of 180,000 page views a day, totaling 7.5 million views over the duration of the program. The campaign message was clear with a large majority of respondents in the follow-up survey saying they understood the intent of "friends or faux"  And that already positive use of Chipotle were strengthened by the program with 3/4 of respondents saying that it made them more interested in eating at Chipotle. But although sales did increase with these promotions in July, our long-term goal remains to engage our customers and educate them about the quality and simplicity of our foods. We also introduced a retro style videogame called Taste Invaders as another entertaining way to point out to customers some of the artificial ingredients found in a typical fast food. The game, which is referred to as a galactic battle against artificial ingredients has been played more than 2 million times and provides another path to learn more about Chipotle, about the food Chipotle serves compared to the vast majority of other chain restaurants. We also continue to advertise nationwide throughout the summer months using traditional online radio and outdoor media. Our goal to educate customers about where our food comes from and the simplicity of our ingredients is also being carried over to our annual promotion and fundraiser this month. Because we always believe that artificial ingredients simply aren't necessary for delicious favorable food, we're asking our customers to add something unnecessary to their costumes October 31 in order to qualify for a $3 burrito. [indiscernible] favorite promotion for our customers and we expect will contribute $1 million to benefit the Chipotle Foundation.
Increasingly, our customers are ordering using their iPhone and Android devices or visiting our website to order online, and we continue to make improvements to enhance and simplify those user experiences. Our mobile and online sales continue to grow for the seventh consecutive quarter and currently represent more than 5% of top line sales, up more than 40% over last year. As we move forward, further investments in those platforms will be made with an eye toward developing tools and technologies to help our restaurant teams better manage and execute our out-of-store orders. Over the next year, we will also continue to improve and simplify our customers' ability to order the meals online. These investments are still at an early stage, but we believe they will help us increase the quality of experience for our guests ordering out of store and will help us grow this promising piece of our business. We've also added a new delivery partnership for customers who prefer that convenience. Ahead of the fall semester colleges and universities across the country, we entered into a delivery partnership with a delivery service that target college campuses and that is already well liked and widely used. We are now delivering to 40 major campuses across country through this partnership. Because it's so tailored to students service includes additional conveniences such as the ability to partner with university payment programs and deliver to dorm rooms and school buildings. marks our third delivery partnership and collectively, these valued delivery partners enable us to offer a delivery service throughout much of the country. Customers also continue to discover our catering. As of tomorrow, it'll be 2 years since we rolled out catering options on a national level, which is available everywhere with the exception of New York City. And while we continue to gain traction in catering, we know there's still work to be done. Part of that work is to test and ultimately roll out online platform that will allow our customers to order and pay for their catering in advance and ultimately, to have those orders delivered. Setting up a delivery for catering is not a simple task, however, particularly when you consider that many of our catering orders are intended to serve up to 200 people. That's a lot of food to be delivered hot, fresh and delicious in a way that meets our high standards and reflects positively on our brand. So we're going to need a partner that has the scale, reach and capability to deliver those large orders, and so we'll be carefully pursuing potential partners and hope to have trials complete in late 2016.
I'll now turn the call over to Jack.

headline: Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark. Overall, we're pleased with the continued strength of our business during the third quarter despite lapping historically high same-store sales comparison from 2014. We continue to grow our comps this quarter by 2.6%, which is on top of last
componenttext:
Thanks, Mark. Overall, we're pleased with the continued strength of our business during the third quarter despite lapping historically high same-store sales comparison from 2014. We continue to grow our comps this quarter by 2.6%, which is on top of last year's comp of 19.8%, our highest as a public company. We're able to continue to grow even as the restaurants achieving volumes of more than $2.5 million on average, all of which can only be accomplished by having top-performing crews and management teams in place that are driven to create an exceptional dining experience for our customers. 
Overall sales for the quarter were up 12% to $1.2 billion, driven by new restaurant openings and a 2.6% comp. Year-to-date sales were $3.5 billion and an increase of 15% over 2014. Our comp increase in the quarter was driven by a 1.9% increase in customer visits, accelerated for the second quarter. Increasingly, more customers are connecting with our vision and appreciate the real food made from wholesome, delicious ingredients using class equipment techniques, and they appreciate that all of that tastes better. Our sales comps were highest in July when our "friends or faux"  Campaign was in full force but were lower in August and September. We were happy with the customer response and engagement with "friends or faux"  During July as our customers who played the game learned about a simple wholesome ingredients and were treated to a BOGO for playing. During the third quarter, we also began implementing a targeted menu price increase in steak and barbacoa due to the sustained state inflation, and we'll continue to roll this out -- roll this increase out across the remaining markets during the fourth quarter. This price increase is expected to contribute about 130 basis points on fully loadout. And for the third quarter, this targeted menu price increase contributed about 70 basis points to the comp. Traffic during the first 2 weeks of October so far has been pretty choppy. But overall, they're averaging about the same as what we saw during August and September, so slightly lower than the overall 2.6% comp in Q3. With the recent return of carnitas to 90% in our restaurant an an expectation of getting back to 100% soon, we would expect Q4 comps will be similar to what we saw in Q3. For the full year we continue to expect our overall comp will be in a low to mid-single digits. And as we look out to 2016, we expect the comps remain in the low single digits. Diluted earnings per share for the quarter was $4.59, an increase of 11%, and year-to-date earnings per share was $12.92, a 26% increase over 2014. With 2000 restaurants in the horizon and our restaurants currently achieving record volumes, we're very confident about what lies ahead as we continue our vision to change people think about and eat fast food.
Restaurant-level margins in the quarter were 28.3%, a decrease [ph] of 50 basis points as higher labor and marketing costs were partially offset by lower food cost. Food costs were 33% in the quarter, down 10 basis points sequentially from Q2 and down 130 basis points compared to 2014. The decrease in the prior year was largely driven by lower cost for avocados and dairy, offset by sustained inflation for We saw minimal inflation for the rest of our food during the quarter, and we expect our food cost to stay in line with recent results through the end of the year. Our pricing for avocados has benefited this year as robust supply for Mexico helped to keep prices down, while dairy prices remain low due to strong production and increased domestic supply strong U.S. dollar has reduced dairy exports. For 2016, we expect food cost inflation will be relatively flat, and our food cost could decrease slightly depending on what happens to our beef cost. U.S. cost for beef and cattle continue to build, and we may see some relief in the cost of [indiscernible] in beef late in 2016. Labor cost were 22.2% of sales in the quarter, an increase of 100 basis points from last year, and year-to-date labor costs were up 40 basis points. After our last call in July, we made significant progress in reducing our labor costs and efficiencies and return to what we consider to be normal labor management and scheduling practices. This resulted in Q3 labor being lower than Q2 by 40 basis points. Labor delevered versus last year by 100 basis points as a result of wage inflation with our hourly wages up nearly 5% over last year along with the cost of adding enhanced benefit such as tuition reimbursement, paid sick leave and increased paid vacation for our hourly restaurant employees as we discussed during our Q2 earnings call. Going forward, we expect labor to be slightly higher than Q3 in the fourth quarter during the seasonally lower sales period. 
[indiscernible] costs were flat in the quarter compared to last year and not to mention, we're lowering our development cost, which will strengthen our unit economic model. Other operating cost were 11.1% in the quarter, an increase of 90 basis points versus last year, largely due to the timing of marketing and promotions this year, including our "friends or faux" game and increased spending surrounding some advertising to keep Chipotle top of mind. Marketing was 1.5% of sales in the quarter, up 20 basis points from last year and is expected to decline slightly in the fourth quarter. Promotion costs were 90 basis points during the quarter, up from 50 basis points last year. For 2016, we anticipate marketing expenses to remain right around 1.5% to 1.6% of sales. G&A expense were 5.8% during the quarter, down 80 basis points the prior year. And remember that 2014 included our biennial All Managers' Conference, which also will occur in 2016. The conference costs around $10 million in 2014 and is expected to cost around $12 million in 2016. Lower stock-based compensation expense and lower bonus costs are also benefiting G&A for the quarter and for the year-to-date. Our noncash noneconomic stock comp expense of $20.7 million in the quarter, down slightly from last year. And for the first 9 months, stock comp expense was $58.6 million, down from $83 million last year, and we expect the full year charge this year will be about $78 million. During 2016, we expect our G&A including stock-based comp to grow at a slower rate than sales before considering the impact of the All Managers' Conference. Stock comp for 2016 will depend on the stock price at the time of the grant and the number and the types of equity awards issued. Our effective tax rate for the quarter was 38.7%, and we expect our effective full year rate to also be 38.7%, and that compared to 37.6% for the full year 2014. The tax rate in 2014 benefited from an increase in the estimated -- estimate of useful tax credits and opportunity and the R&D federal tax credit, which have not been renewed by Congress for 2015. If those federal credits are extended to 2015, we estimate our tax rate would benefit by about 40 basis points. And our estimated effective tax rate for 2016 is expected to remain at around 38.7%.
During the quarter, we repurchased about a $30 million of our stock or approximately 46,000 shares at an average share price of $670. At the end of the third quarter, we had $155 million remaining on our share buyback program. We finished the quarter with $1.58 billion in cash and cash equivalents with no debt on the balance sheet, and we continue to believe this use of cash investment in opening our high-returning Chipotle restaurant in the U.S. and will continue to nurture our growth seeds including ShopHouse and Pizzeria Locale and our international Chipotle restaurants so they will become a compelling use of capital in the future. In the meantime, we'll continue to repurchase shares of our stock opportunistically to enhance shareholder value. Thanks for your time today, and we'll be happy to open the lines for any questions you may have.

headline: Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Sharon Zackfia with William Blair.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Sharon Zackfia with William Blair.

headline: Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: So just a few questions, Jack. I guess on carnitas, have you been seeing a bump then when carnitas returned to the restaurants. I know, originally, you thought it was about a 200 basis point penalty. And then separately on labor, I guess on the wage infla
componenttext: So just a few questions, Jack. I guess on carnitas, have you been seeing a bump then when carnitas returned to the restaurants. I know, originally, you thought it was about a 200 basis point penalty. And then separately on labor, I guess on the wage inflation as 5%, can you kind of dimensionalize what you think your underlying wage inflation? I think you did some sort of step-up or adjustment in your wage schedule. I'm not sure how much of that was proactive versus reactive in what might be the ongoing run rate for 2016 for your wage inflation.

headline: Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. On carnitas, it's hard to tell because we did return to 90, and we finished September like just under 60%. We did hit 90 in the the second half of September. It did look like in the markets that it did get carnitas back that we did see some imp
componenttext: Yes, sure. On carnitas, it's hard to tell because we did return to 90, and we finished September like just under 60%. We did hit 90 in the the second half of September. It did look like in the markets that it did get carnitas back that we did see some improvement during the second week of October, but October has been so choppy so far that's hard to tell. We did expect that based on when we suspended the sale of carnitas, we did see what we thought could be as much as a 200 basis point negative impact on the comps, so we're hoping we'll see that return, but it will take a little bit more time for us to fully see that happen. In terms of the wage inflation, a lot of that was proactive. We did have some isolated areas. We had San Francisco. We had parts of D.C. where there were minimal wage increases. And in most markets, we're above minimum wage, so it doesn't happen have an immediate impact. But just because of general competition for employees, just the expectation that we want to hire top performers, we want to be employer of choice, we want to be very proactive in making sure that not only are starting wages are competitive, but we also took a look at the number of our hourly managers during the summer to make sure that we're paying fair rates to them as well. So that was proactive in terms of what to expect going forward. I think it depends what the labor market looks like. I wouldn't expect it would stay at fully 5% year-after-year, so I don't know if it would compound all the way to 5%, but I don't know that it's going to drop all the way down to 2%, which is what it had been running for the last, I'd say, 2 or 3 or 4 years.

headline: Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to David Tarantino with Baird.
componenttext: We'll go next to David Tarantino with Baird.

headline: Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jack, just a question on how you're viewing the recent trends in your business. And I know you mentioned that August and September are a little slower than July. Do you think you've seen a change in the underlying momentum of the business? Or is that just
componenttext: Jack, just a question on how you're viewing the recent trends in your business. And I know you mentioned that August and September are a little slower than July. Do you think you've seen a change in the underlying momentum of the business? Or is that just more so related to the benefit you saw from the "buy one get one free" promotion.

headline: Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, definitely, David, the reason I wanted to go through the monthly comps is July, we benefited. There was a lot of awareness, a lot of people playing the games, a lot of people earning and that are regaining to buy-one-get-one and that always results
componenttext: Well, definitely, David, the reason I wanted to go through the monthly comps is July, we benefited. There was a lot of awareness, a lot of people playing the games, a lot of people earning and that are regaining to buy-one-get-one and that always results in a short-term bump in sales. So I would say that July moving to September -- or moving to August was more kind of a hangover effect from "friends or faux," but we're kind of holding at that lower level, that low single-digit level. Some of that also is due to very, very tough comparisons to last year, so I would say we're kind of just holding our own right now. I wouldn't say after the July bumped that we got "friends or faux,"  I would say we're just kind of holding our own. I don't think we're accelerating. We're not decelerating, but I don't think us accelerating either.

headline: Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. That's helpful. Maybe a second question, you hired a new Chief Technology Officer recently, and I'm wondering kind of big picture what we should expect to see from that higher, does that include perhaps the strengthening of the mobile ordering plat
componenttext: Great. That's helpful. Maybe a second question, you hired a new Chief Technology Officer recently, and I'm wondering kind of big picture what we should expect to see from that higher, does that include perhaps the strengthening of the mobile ordering platform or any of the other elements related to that.

headline: Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, David, he hasn't even started yet, so it'd be premature to say exactly what we're going to do. But one way we think about the business is about 2/3 of our business is eaten outside of the restaurant, but only 7% of our business is ordered outside of
componenttext: Yes, David, he hasn't even started yet, so it'd be premature to say exactly what we're going to do. But one way we think about the business is about 2/3 of our business is eaten outside of the restaurant, but only 7% of our business is ordered outside of a restaurant. And so there's a big gap between our customers who choose to or end up eating somewhere else other than a restaurant. So it kind of make sense for us to provide the convenience to order outside of a restaurant, and we do have the iPhone, we do have Android, but we can make that the whole process more efficiently, we can make it more reliable. And our customers, they would love to go through the line because they have complete control, but I think there are ways for us to between focus on operation and second make line that Monty talked about as well as looking out what technology opportunities are there. I think we can enhance our overall experience so that 7% continues to grow over time.

headline: Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2015

componenttext: And then just following up on that, so the ultimate impact in both Q2 transaction in mix, what was that for the quarter as well?

componenttext: Well, the overall quarter we did a 2.6% comp, 1.9% was transaction and 0.7% -- 70 basis points was for our menu price increase. And that was the targeted -- vast majority was targeted menu price increase related to our steak and barbacoa.

headline: Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to David Palmer with RBC.
componenttext: We'll go next to David Palmer with RBC.

headline: Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your throughput, you mentioned the lunch hour declined a little bit. I realized peak daypart and peak season, but how important do you think that was? And are you contemplating any significant adjustments to drive throughput?
componenttext: Your throughput, you mentioned the lunch hour declined a little bit. I realized peak daypart and peak season, but how important do you think that was? And are you contemplating any significant adjustments to drive throughput?

headline: Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I always think it's really important to focus throughput. And obviously, coming off -- we're sort of coming off our seasonality in terms of the credits coming through our restaurants. And then simultaneously with sort of lower transaction com
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I always think it's really important to focus throughput. And obviously, coming off -- we're sort of coming off our seasonality in terms of the credits coming through our restaurants. And then simultaneously with sort of lower transaction comp that we've been experiencing, I think what happens is sometimes our teams get focused on a number of other things staffing being "A Model," training new managers, onboarding new crews and then I think sometimes when things aren't moving -- when the crews isn't quite as rapid, people get a little less excited about pushing on -- pushing throughput and really watching their 4 pillars execution. So I think it's kind of a long way of saying I think we put our eye off the ball a little bit. It could happen sometimes, especially after a year of sort of blistering comps of sort of 19.8% a year ago during this time. Doing those times, it's very easy to keep throughput top of mind and have our crews be focused intensely on it. We had contests running, we had people excited about bringing throughput records and just a lot of focus on it, and I think that the focus has waned a little bit, and that is not -- that's not saying we want to see continue because throughput even during slower growth times, we have lines, and we had lines that caused some people to walk away. And we are going to work to replenish and reinvigorate our teams to focus on throughput and on execution of the 4 pillars of throughput because it is still an enormously huge competitive advantage for us and a huge part of customer service. So even if it's only a fall-off of one transaction, we do look to gain transactions. And as you've seen from the previous several years, we gained -- even at our core lunch hour, we had gained transactions almost every quarter. And so we don't like to see it fall off, one. But we're glad to have attained the real significant gains we made during 2013 and '14, but we'd like to improve on that still more.

headline: Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a quick follow-up on David's question on mobile order. The fact that you have mobile order already, a lot of people are focusing on that for Starbucks, and it's making great strides for them. you improved your mobile order earlier this year. It feels
componenttext: Just a quick follow-up on David's question on mobile order. The fact that you have mobile order already, a lot of people are focusing on that for Starbucks, and it's making great strides for them. you improved your mobile order earlier this year. It feels like a lot of people don't know about it, just to some degree just about marketing what you have or do you think this is going to be more about improving the mobile order technology in some way?

headline: Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we've deliberately undermarketed our mobile ordering, and the reason for that is fairly simple. We just have not quite optimized the experience in the restaurants to the point where we feel comfortable driving a large number of people in there, and
componenttext: Well, we've deliberately undermarketed our mobile ordering, and the reason for that is fairly simple. We just have not quite optimized the experience in the restaurants to the point where we feel comfortable driving a large number of people in there, and we're working on all of those improvements. So we don't want somebody to go in and have a make a mobile order and go in and have a degraded experience. So all of the growth that we've seen on mobile has essentially been without any marketing at all. So there's a tremendous amount of potential. But as we talked about in our prepared comments, we really want to optimize the experience before we really drive people in there the mobile experience.

headline: Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Additionally, we think that we have the ability to drive a lot of traffic to -- through mobile ordering and that will go to our second make line in the back of the house. We think that potentially we could overwhelm that second line, so we have started to
componenttext: Additionally, we think that we have the ability to drive a lot of traffic to -- through mobile ordering and that will go to our second make line in the back of the house. We think that potentially we could overwhelm that second line, so we have started to retool that second make line to have at least the same capacity as our main line. By the way, it doesn't take extra space in the kitchen, which is good news, but it does take some retooling. So it needs to be a combination of both the marketing of that -- of that technology with increasing the capacity of the second make line.

headline: Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Andrew Charles with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: We'll go next to Andrew Charles with Cowen and Company.

headline: Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: On the same-store sales guidance, it seems low single-digit for 2016 reflects significant deceleration on a 2- and 3-year basis. Of course, there's some price that's likely to fall off, but what are other factors driving deceleration? Or would you say tha
componenttext: On the same-store sales guidance, it seems low single-digit for 2016 reflects significant deceleration on a 2- and 3-year basis. Of course, there's some price that's likely to fall off, but what are other factors driving deceleration? Or would you say that low single digit is a function more of conservatism?

headline: Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the way I would think about it, Andrew, is that we just finished a 3-year trend, and I talked about this on some earlier calls. If you go back and look to 2013, we started a new trend where we started in low single-digit comps, and we kind of built
componenttext: Well, the way I would think about it, Andrew, is that we just finished a 3-year trend, and I talked about this on some earlier calls. If you go back and look to 2013, we started a new trend where we started in low single-digit comps, and we kind of built our comps for the next several quarters. We had price increase in 2014. But if you combine the last 3 years, and this is kind of the end of that trend, our 3-year comps are up in the high 27%, 28% range. We now need to start a new trend because we started that momentum. And if you look quarter by quarter-to-quarter, you can see that the momentum built for several quarters, that levels off. It peaked last year at 19.8. And then as you're comparing to multiple years of double-digit comps, and none of this is based on gimmicks, on promotions on discounting or like that, it's really just inviting more customers, and they have great experience, they want to come back. There's an education that market and the team have done with things like scarecrow and things that raise the awareness of where food comes from, why our food is different, and our customers have been able during this 3-year trend to connect the dots between why the food they love so much tastes so good, because they come from these great ingredients, because the food is prepared using classic cooking techniques or real cooking going on in their restaurants. So right now, we're this challenge where we got 3 years of growing our sales by 27%, 28% and comparing to that is difficult. So what we're hoping will happen is we'll be able to ignite another trend, another 3-year trend. When that will happen with the order of magnitude of that happening is very difficult to predict. But over the last 10, 15 years, Chipotle has seen these kind of ways of comps, and most of it is around bringing awareness and appreciation for what we do at Chipotle.

headline: Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Steve, just a separate question, just in answer to the last question, you talked about you need to retool the second make line. It's not going to evolve extra room. But can you give us a sense for what really needs to be done there the sense of exec
componenttext: Okay. Steve, just a separate question, just in answer to the last question, you talked about you need to retool the second make line. It's not going to evolve extra room. But can you give us a sense for what really needs to be done there the sense of execution for 4 pillars and more labor training? Any kind of direction will be helpful.

headline: Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: It wouldn't be 4 pillars in that there's a dedicated crew person or 2 depending on volume to that make line. So it's not the same deployment, but there are a lot of things -- having to do with capacity of the insides as you hold hot and cold food, the ins
componenttext: It wouldn't be 4 pillars in that there's a dedicated crew person or 2 depending on volume to that make line. So it's not the same deployment, but there are a lot of things -- having to do with capacity of the insides as you hold hot and cold food, the insides right now is very small. So retooling that to have larger capacity. Also, the way we scoop can be improved using different kinds of utensils that are more efficient that might not be appropriate for the ma inline but are very efficient in the back of the house. And then also the way orders come in. Right now, they come in on a paper chip, if you will, which have to be read. So there are different technologies that we are looking at right now, and we've been going through this process to determine which one is going to be best for us, but they involve different ways that the orders can be indicated to the crew people, so that they can make these orders much faster, much more efficiently. So it's an exciting project, and it's moving fast and keeping pace with the ability to roll out the technology.

And I know you gave some color on October, but any more color in terms of what the composition of the comp has been so far in October? And then I just had a follow-up.

headline: Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: October would be similar, but there may be a little bit more menu pricing in October, but not much more. I would say the makeup of the comp is similar in terms of we're running about a 70 basis point price increase, maybe at 80 or 90, something like that.
componenttext: October would be similar, but there may be a little bit more menu pricing in October, but not much more. I would say the makeup of the comp is similar in terms of we're running about a 70 basis point price increase, maybe at 80 or 90, something like that. We will gradually get that up to 130. We hope it does prove to be conservative, and maybe it is conservative, but October is so choppy right now. It really isn't giving us any indication of what the current underlying pattern is. And so I hope that that when we report in January, we'll come back, and you all say, "Ah, you guys were too conservative." But right now, with what we saw finishing the quarter and what we saw in October being very, very choppy, it's very difficult to read.

headline: Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2015

componenttext: Got it. Okay. And just actually in response to the last question, I mean I know you commented that you had seen waves of comps, and I think what you said the waves generally revolve around awareness. But I guess maybe a little color, it's history on what has driven your comps really relevant I guess in terms of what might drive the next wave? I guess, the way I see it, I mean, the competitive environment has and is changing rapidly as is technology. So maybe just your thoughts there.

headline: Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, of course, our comps going forward are likely to be different than historical, but we still find that there's lots of people that either aren't aware of Chipotle or they're aware Chipotle, but they don't know about where our food comes from. They do
componenttext: Well, of course, our comps going forward are likely to be different than historical, but we still find that there's lots of people that either aren't aware of Chipotle or they're aware Chipotle, but they don't know about where our food comes from. They don't know that we're doing real cooking. This happens to all the time. We've got an email from a former colleague of ours within Florida, and he says, "Out of 10 people, as many as 7 or 8 or 9 of them have never been to Chipotle before." So there's still this opportunity to educate people one that that is changing over time because as we are in more markets, more people know about Chipotle, but they don't necessarily know that we're using classic cooking techniques. They don't necessarily know that we do things like source naturally raised meats, and we have a local program during the right season and things like that. And so that's something that we all bump into people all the time that don't fully understand that. So there's still awareness around why Chipotle is different. There's a lot of competitors out there the messaging more difficult that our messaging that we're doing something that's more natural or that would imply that this higher quality there so that this makes the message more clear. But we believe that the source of where our comp will come from will still come from educating people about Chipotle, increasing the awareness about why we are different from others. And we had a great experience where people come in and try Chipotle, and they have a great dining experience, they tend to want to come back. And so while yes, it's more challenging; yes, we have higher volumes; yes, there are more competitors; generally, our job, our challenge is to get more people to understand and come to Chipotle more often.

headline: Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: And as you're thinking about next year and we do have some wage pressures, it sounds like food cost not really a big pressure. How are you thinking about the next wave of pricing when you want to start looking at that? Is wage pressure is something that y
componenttext: And as you're thinking about next year and we do have some wage pressures, it sounds like food cost not really a big pressure. How are you thinking about the next wave of pricing when you want to start looking at that? Is wage pressure is something that you want to get ahead of as we get into next year?

headline: Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we don't have any plans right now for any kind of a national price increase to deal with wage pressure, but we do have a number of isolated markets, a number of which are coming up in January. We'll take the same approach that we hope with we talked
componenttext: Yes, we don't have any plans right now for any kind of a national price increase to deal with wage pressure, but we do have a number of isolated markets, a number of which are coming up in January. We'll take the same approach that we hope with we talked about it on the last quarter, and it was in the San Francisco area and also in the -- I think it was the mid-Atlantic area a couple of markets that had pretty significant increases in minimum wage. Generally, we're not affected by minimum wage, but in some cases, minimum wages are being increased to $10, $11, $12 per hour, and those will have an impact. We don't automatically increase prices in those markets. What we do is we look at all the cost of doing business in that area. And the 2 cases that we mentioned last quarter, we increased prices there because not only are wages up, but those areas already have higher cost of doing business, things like higher occupancy cost and local taxes and things like that. And when we look to competition, the competition was pretty aggressive in raising prices, so we do the same thing with minimum wage increases on a market-by-market basis, and we'll make the decisions market-by-market basis based on the wages, other cost of business, what the competitors are doing and what our current margins, we'll consider all those factors.

headline: Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jack, you highlighted $1.58 billion in cash. You highlighted how the best use of that is to put it towards new unit opens. You're already accelerating Chipotle opens this year it's above target. Next year, it's even more. How close are we to accelerating
componenttext: Jack, you highlighted $1.58 billion in cash. You highlighted how the best use of that is to put it towards new unit opens. You're already accelerating Chipotle opens this year it's above target. Next year, it's even more. How close are we to accelerating the unit open for ShopHouse and Pizzeria Locale?

headline: Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: I hate to put a time line on it. We are accelerating to a certain degree, but I assume what you really mean is to ramp it up aggressively. They're still in the nurturing phase. They're still in the brand-building phase. When we open up a new restaurant, i
componenttext: I hate to put a time line on it. We are accelerating to a certain degree, but I assume what you really mean is to ramp it up aggressively. They're still in the nurturing phase. They're still in the brand-building phase. When we open up a new restaurant, it behaves a lot like Chipotle. 12, 15 years ago, when we went into a new market it's an unfamiliar brand, it takes a while for customers to figure out what ShopHouse is. Pizzeria Locale, while it's pizza, it's that may be familiar to customers used to traditional pizza. So there's still a brand building and an understanding of what we're doing, very similar to what we saw an Chipotle in early days. We see encouraging signs like we're seeing some very strong comps in the markets that we've opened is why we've done things like with ShopHouse, we're going to open a new market in Chicago. And so it gives us now 3 different markets where the brand building and awareness is being created. With Pizzeria Locale, same thing. We will -- very soon, we're in 2 markets right now. we'll be in the third market. I think we're planting the right seeds. We're doing it in a number of markets where more and more customers will be able to visit these restaurants to figure out what's different about ShopHouse, Pizzeria Locale. And as we see, the awareness the comps continue to build, just like we do with Chipotle early days, we'll continue to invest in those markets. And very similar reaction to what we're seeing in Europe, we're seeing very attractive sales comps, we're seeing some inconsistency in stores open. Some open hot and open up pretty high right away, and some will take a little time to build. So there's still what we consider to be an early brand building stage, but we're seeing some encouraging sign.

headline: Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: And maybe one quick one for Mark. If we're really going through this 3-year cycle, this is a point where the company is very well flushed with cash, the traffic is a bit lower in this part of the 3-year cycle. When we talked about some of these other awar
componenttext: And maybe one quick one for Mark. If we're really going through this 3-year cycle, this is a point where the company is very well flushed with cash, the traffic is a bit lower in this part of the 3-year cycle. When we talked about some of these other awareness issues, why not use this as a perfect opportunity to put some money into the marketing program for long-term brand awareness, long-term brand building actions to kind of cement that relationship and awareness for the Food with Integrity? Why not step up some of those efforts a little more at this part of the cycle?

headline: Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I'd say we are probably stepping it up in some regards. I mean one thing, I think, important to understand about our strategy here is we deliberately spent less on our marketing, so that we can afford these higher-quality ingredients. And that's ess
componenttext: Well, I'd say we are probably stepping it up in some regards. I mean one thing, I think, important to understand about our strategy here is we deliberately spent less on our marketing, so that we can afford these higher-quality ingredients. And that's essentially the main benefit, the main marketing benefit to our customers. And so we find different ways to tell that story, entertaining ways to do it, but we have recently shifted our focus more to telling the basic story about where our ingredients come from and how they're made, and we significantly increased our focus on digital marketing, very effective we're going to be using some of our in-store assets to communicate some of these messages like our packaging. And so I think we're doing it. I think what you won't see from us though is some people might think ramping up would mean the television, something like that. The problem with television the R&D expense is really, really tailored toward 30-second spots, which really only deliver if you have some sort of a promotional call-to-action message in them which is a very slippery slope. So we're going to stay the course of telling this brand story, but we're working on several large initiatives, some of -- similar to the ones you've seen in the past as well as what I just mentioned, which has an increased focus on digital and in-store communication. So I'd say we are ramping it up in some way, yes.

componenttext: And then just a big picture question with the acceleration in development, are you finding more sites that are perfect for Chipotle? Or this is also the benefit of the nearly 5,000 hires you made recently that Monty was talking about earlier?

headline: Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, this is really -- this is really -- that we are gaining -- our real estate people throughout the field are gaining confidence in that we have gone into a lot of smaller or sort of fewer markets or off-the-beaten-path markets lately with a lot of succe
componenttext: No, this is really -- this is really -- that we are gaining -- our real estate people throughout the field are gaining confidence in that we have gone into a lot of smaller or sort of fewer markets or off-the-beaten-path markets lately with a lot of success, and our new store openings continue to be at a very solid volume. And so I guess just the confidence of our teams in the field who are out looking for real estate is very, very high that they can confidently sign deals. And so they've been -- and also, we're better known than ever as a tenant. We're better trusted than ever by landlords, and so we're very sought after tenant. And given the little bit better availability of volume and people are going to build an end cap with us in mind and build a 3-unit complex and put us in it, and so we are able to just find a who lot of deals even the walking away from deals and striking a relatively a harder bargain. And also, our team has been organized in a way that's more efficient that's allowed us to work really well together. And with increased confidence, the team is just feeling great, and they're producing a lot of great sites with really great terms and building these things for less than we did last year, which is superb. But it really isn't any result of our hiring. Our hiring is something we did because we're really trying to become staffed at our existing restaurants to have an advocate complement of people to build for future leadership and have a great base and being able to build when we open new restaurants.
